comments.commentBody:
I doubt few appreciate anyone, let alone some detached program, digging around in our psyches. Who doesn't have moments of sadness, grief or at times feelings of desperation.

Privacy is a precious thing. What one shares online or elsewhere should be solely that person's right to share, and with whom to share.
We must hope we are not judged by the friends we keep, and especially not those we put in place and support with much killing. For every ugly friend of Putin, we've got a few of our own.
Why? We weren't the regime that harmed them. We don't have any obligation to do what you suggest.
No matter the $100 figure, for decades every Cuban has had better access to health care and better health care than millions of U.S. citizens. Cubans are alive who'd be dead in the U.S.
Should they ever get the chance to get their property back in Cuba, it will be interesting to see which citizenship they choose.

The especially rabid types who define their life by hatred of Castro will have to find a new and more productive way to define themselves. It is in the interests of the USA to establish dialogue with Cuba, so it will move ahead with or without them.
You have one zero too much - 50k is correct.
Hear Hear! Battista was thrown out for a reason. And the U.S. supported him the same way they supported Pinochet and Reza Pahlavi. And that didn't end well IIRC.

Maybe someone out there who is so upset with the United States normalizing relations with Cuba can enlighten me as to what was so darned wonderful about Fulgencio Batista, the former dictator of Cuba?  We had full relations with him (and no, I am not naive, I know why).  Marco Rubio's parents emigrated from Batista's Cuba in 1956 as did many others during his time as dictator.  There would not have been a Fidel Castro takeover of Cuba if Batista had not been so corrupt and brutal.

Vietnam is a capitalistic country. Oh you don't believe it, visit it. Basically people put up with their government. Time will change everything. Same with China. Same with Cuba. People want to live their lives and given the chance in a free market society they will. People want a chance to make some money buy a house, car, educate their children. Government in many cases is just a hindrance, an annoyance. We have it better but given the chance Cuba, China, and a host of other countries that have a free market economy will have their freedoms. Change will happen slowly. First in their homes then with luck their institutions. All will democratize in some way over time.
Too much government control, so that when markets failed the private sector couldn't self correct.

Not that conservatives were ever great with facts, but the catastrophic debacles in Iraq/Afghanistan and the economic collapse in 2007/08 represented a massive challenge to conservative ideology. Conservatives had one of two choices. They could either reexamine some of their basic beliefs, or they could deny reality and ignore facts. It's proven much easier to follow the latter course than the former.

To those conservatives out there who think I'm spouting left-wing ideology, please offer your explanation for the 2007/08 economic collapse that includes Wall Street's role in the collapse. Every conservative description of what happened in 2007/08 either leaves Wall Street out completely or makes them out to be a weak victim in all of this that played no role whatsoever.

Yes, what will actually change?

Americans are busy patting themselves on the back and defending Obama's move, but will it be like his many other moves, a big show with little substance behind it?
So what is your solution?  Another 50 plus years of ignoring a country 90 miles from our shoreline?    Talk about being mired in the big muddy.
Well, the status quo hasn't brought any positive results so it's a smart move to opt for change instead of sticking with fifty years of failure.

I read many of the comments and wonder how many of the people writing them read more than the headlines.

The dissidents in question are Cubans living in Cuba, who have not immigrated to the United States or elsewhere, such as the Ladies in White. Their concerns voice the concerns of many Cubans, and their concerns are not inimical to the resolution to the vast material want that plagues the island.

A material want which is the result of the failures of communism itself, not the American embargo, as Cuba has traded with the rest of the world for years.

Their worries are justified, especially after the speech that Raul Castro delivered last Saturday essentially dashing hopes for even small change. Instead, it sounded more like a reiteration of the old authoritarian ways, especially now that the United States is throwing a hard-currency lifeline with very little being asked by the US in return.

Putin does not 'jail his enemies' any more than Obama or Cameron does. One of his greatest enemies is Marsha Gessen: she wrote the enthusiastic attack on him 'the Man Without a Face'; she writes regular articles attacking him in the NYT, New Statesman, Vanity Fair, et al; and she is dragged out for appearances on talk shows when they want someone who will put the boots into Putin.
She lives freely in Moscow as a dual Russian/American citizen and has never, as far as I know, seen the inside of a jail, in Moscow or elsewhere.

Putin's main problem is that he doesn't have the finesse that the US has in camouflaging it's relationships with dictatorships and countries that ignore human rights, etc. Not quite democracies. Our duplicitous relationships with Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and China stand out. Tell me again why Iran is worse than any of these folks?

Mr Appledorf,

Justifying or accepting the acts of Putin based on the debacles of past US Presidents (Iraq, Vietnam, etc) is hardly a path to a better world. I think many Americans opposed these colossal blunders from the beginning and the vast majority of Americans now believe they were both wrong and costly in lives and treasure, sold to the public and allies through a series of assurances and lies now apparent through the lens of history.

The collective memory of Vietnam still echoes in the present, as Iraq will in the future. I think you'll see the US move away from previous strong allies like the Saudis to a more balanced and less interventionist Middle East policy.

Likewise, the terrible memory of the Soviet occupation of Eastern Europe still inspires a rational fear of Russian expansionism.

The path forward, interrupted temporarily by Putin, is engagement between Russia and Europe to modernize and diversify the Russian economy for the benefit of the larger population, much as happened in China.

I find it wearisome being one tiny voice protesting incessant Putin bashing in the pages of the NY times. Mr. Putin should know that for one reader of this newspaper time does not begin when the NY Times says it does.

Mr. Putin took Crimea because his national security was threatened. His navy was tied up in a base nominally under control of a government that had assumed power in the wake of a violent coup supported by the USA.

U.S. aggression always comes masked by accusations of aggression by the target of U.S. aggression. There is always a Tonkin Gulf, a mushroom cloud smoking gun, an imminent invasion of Texas by the USSR.

Mr. Putin is responsible for the interests of Russia on a world stage that is dominated by the ruthlessness, violence, and duplicity of the USA. Russia is not Shangrila, and I doubt if Russia claims to be. But the relentless hostility of the USA toward Russia and its leadership is, as I said, tiring.

The USA does not have oligarchs sucking the life blood out of the American body politic? The American oligarchs go one better: they suck the life out of the entire world. Russian violence? Yes, Chechnya has been devastated. Need we mention Iraq? And that is just for starters.

The sanctimony wears thin after a while. All this carrot-and-stick talk in American-Russian relations is predicated on the unremitting hostility of the USA towards Russia. Full stop. Absent that there is no issue that the U.S. and Mr. Putin could not resolve.

It could also lead Putin to conclude that "a threat to its security and existence" justifies an invasion. He could do it in weeks, and no, the US will not fight a war with Russia to undo it. NATO certainly wouldn't, the British already have said so, and they're our poodles in such things. Be careful of how far we push into things we won't follow up. We learned that with Hungary in 1956.

This makes it sound as if Putin planned to do Crimea after Sochi. Everyone of good sense, even Kissinger, has said he was reacting in surprise to a US move. He didn't plan that, he made it up as he went. It was not at all where he expected things to go when he was enjoying Sochi.

Cuban exiles and conservatives say that lifting the embargo will allow the Castro Regime to continue. And they're probably right. But then so will keeping the embargo up. So I ask, what the Hell is the point of the embargo? It's accomplished nothing but to serve as an impediment in America's Latin American foreign policy.
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child defines child as "a human being below the age of 18 years unless under the law applicable to the child, majority is attained earlier".[
14 is still a kid, a teenager but still a minor and not fully capable of making informed & rational decisions.

Sadly, "adults" are also very easily indoctrinated into certain ideologies willingly and passionately accepting the teachings of religious or political zealots aided and abetted by Fox News et al. America it's long past time to look in the mirror. God deliver us all from hatred of "the other".

I wish you would all grow up. In America 14 years old is a "child" and all too often so is 30 and 50. In most of the world a 14 year old is a young man capable of dealing with adult decisions, in his early stages of experience, certainly, but a young adult not a "child.

It is a demeaning insult to treat teenagers as "children" unless they are from one of the few countries, such as ours, where their education retards their brain's ability to make young adult decisions.

Those who decide to blow themselves up are just as adult as Usaid, but simply came to an opposite decision of which we disapprove.

You may have noticed that everyone in the adult world does not agree with our point of view, regardless of their age.

The London Review of Books, 18 December 2014 has a long a devastating review of 4 books about Britain's role in the Afghan conflict. "Worse than a Defeat" by James Meek. p 3
"The Good War: Why We Couldn't Win the War or the Peace in Afghanistan" by Jack Fairweather. "Investment in Blood: The True Cost of Britain's Afghan War" by Frank Ledwidge. "British Generals in Blair's Wars" ed by Jonathan Bailey, Richard Iron and Hew Strachan. "An Intimate War: An Oral History of The Helmand Conflict 1978-2012" by Mike Martin.
Not cheerful reading. Rajiv Chandrasekaran's book on Afghanistan also focuses on Helmand.

No boom or bust is like the last one. Things change. Many producers hedge their production out up to three years (some are required to by lenders), so only the most levered, highest-cost producers will fail, only to be snapped up by private-equity-backed companies. Energy-focused investment funds were few a decade or two ago -- now they have billions under management. When fundamentals return, exploration will resume.

There will be an impact as drilling is reduced, but it will be muted and, in many cases, spread over a wide area. Oil patch veterans know that fundamentally oil and gas are commodities, subject to such swings, and you don't plan your business or base-level revenues off of peak pricing. I guess we'll see how diversified we have become down here.

I'm not too concerned about oil workers, Jeff. Having briefly worked in the oil business in Houston, I say with certainty that Texas oil workers don't spend much time or money in New York. Nor do they read. Especially, the NY Times. As for Hawaii, they will have big problems because so many Alaskans visit there. Those poor Hawaiians never catch a break. First the Americans ransack their culture, heritage, and land and then they get hammered by a fluctuating tourist economy that is not of their own making.
California is far from being in trouble - things are great. And, actually, we sink or swim together, you should know.
The blue states are in trouble? You mean a few red states, right?

California is in great shape and is the envy of the nation.

You are referring to the red states listed in this article - Texas, Alaska, etc. - who have built their economic base on oil.

We're smarter than that.

Great strategy by Obama. Low oil prices bankrupt Russia, Iran and other non-US  friendly countries. More importantly, the blue states are in trouble. Do people talk about the Keystone pipeline anymore? It is going to change the politics in the next election too.
Let's not castigate Mr. Brennan  too much.  Let's NOT forget that he serves at the pleasure of President Obama.  The buck stops at the President's desk.

To our great misfortune, the national intelligence imperatives continue to be shaped by unprincipled as well as short-term thinkers like Mr. Brennan. For as much distance as exists between Brennan and such discredited predecessors as George Tenant, they still share the conviction that we can prevail over violent Islamic fundamentalism by killing enougn of the right ones.

I doubt "fear in the air" had anything to do with lack of action in this case. At least not the fear of international terrorism, caliphates, etc.

No, much more to the point -- Politicians are fearful of their reputations and the careers relying upon them, both of which are put at direct risk when they question the Agency.

You are challenging a huge body of scientific work with faddishness and pseudo-science. Calories DO count and chick peas are an excellent food for anyone, especially a vegetarian. I have lost weight and maintained it for seven years, by eating less--of a balanced diet. I do eat the occasional egg (with yolk) and enjoy small servings of many types of beans, including chick peas (garbanzo beans).
Amen
Women in Human Resources? Wow, that's something new, isn't it?
I agree that women in human resources is the norm.  I considered noting this in my original comment-- and perhaps I should have-- but I wanted to be even-handed toward Zenefit and Sacks.

I note that Jodi Kantor's NYT article discusses not only the obstacles faced by women in Silicon Valley but also emerging successes. David Sacks's latest venture, Zenefit, which automates human resources functions, has a workforce that is 40% female. According to Ms. Kantor's article, Mr. Sacks also appears to support expanding gender diversity in Silicon Valley. Thus, it would seem that some modest progress is being made.

At the same time, I would have to say that the problems described by Mr. Nocera are common in other fields, too. My field, commercial real estate, is heavily dominated by males, especially in the development sector. To its credit, the Urban Land Institute, a prominent real estate professional association, has started a Women's Initiative, to support women's advancement in the field. This is a good thing, but it's a shame that women's rise in the commercial property industry has been so slow. Although there are exceptions, women and minorities have found advancement through the ranks of commercial real estate tough going.

All told, I'm glad that women and minorities are making progress-- even as I'm saddened that progress has been inadequate. I agree with Joe Nocera that most executives hire and promote in their own image, even as they insist that merit is their sole criterion.
I tried to read his first book in the series, but couldn't maintain an interest. One of the few books I've started and set aside. Many people love Mr. Larrson' s books, but they don't do it for me.
